field_speakers.processed: Mary Gallagher (University of Michigan), Margaret Lewis (Seton Hall Law School), Rory Truex (Princeton University), Jacques deLisle (University of Pennsylvania)

field_organizers.processed: National Committee on U.S.-China Relations, Penn Center for the Study of Contermporary China

field_description.processed: The downturn in U.S.-China relations has strained once robust educational and research ties. China has restricted opportunities for contact between American and Chinese scholars and students, while in the United States, concerns about national security, intellectual property loss, Chinese competitiveness, and “pro-China” views on U.S. campuses have triggered a variety of responses including visa denials, re-evaluation of faculty ties to Chinese institutions, and federal prosecutions. Are the core American values of open research and academic freedom at risk as a result? NB: This program is held in partnership with the Penn Project on the Future of US-China Relations, sponsored by the University of Pennsylvania’s Center for the Study of Contemporary China.
